g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute

industrial levels. AR5 noted that mitigation effort and the costs
associated with ambitious mitigation differ significantly across countries, and in ‘globally cost
effective’ scenarios, the biggest reductions (relative to projections) occ

of the shift in investments and strategies will be crucial
A key message from recent Special Reports is the urgency to mitigate GHG emissions in order to avoid
rapid and potentially irreversible changes in natural and human sy
Successive IPCC reports have drawn upon increasing sophistication of modelling tools to project
in the absence of ambitious decarbonisation action, as well as the emission pathways that
meet long term temperature targets. The SR1.5
decline by about 45% from 2010 levels by 2030,
brought down by 2100 through ‘net negative’ emissions. It found this
reaching transitions in energy, land, urban and infrastructure (including transport and
Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) as declared under the Paris
would not limit warming to 1.5 C
; despite significant updates to NDCs in 2020/21,

and the Special Reports analysed economic costs associated with climate action. The
estimates vary widely depending on the assumptions made as to
, the metric or model used, among others (
Modelled direct mitigation costs of pathways to 1.5°C, with no/limited overshoot, span a wide range,

of benefits, including significant reduction in loss
of life and livelihoods, and avoided climate impacts
Successive IPCC Reports highlight a strong connection between climate mitigation and sustainable
development. Climate mitigation and adaptation goals have synergie
achieve sustainable development, including poverty eradication.
climate policy therefore involves going beyond a narrow focus on specific mitigation and adaptation
e issues into the design of comprehensive strategies for equitable
sustainable development. At the same time, some climate mitigation policies can run counter to
, which highlights the need to consider trade
. Examples include synergies between climate policy and improved air quality,
(IPCC 2014b Fig SPM.6; AR6 WG1 sections 6.6.3 and 6.7.3)
offs if policy raises net energy bills, with distributional implications.
Special Report on Climate Change and Land (SRCCL) also emphasises important synergies and trade
offs, bringing new light on the link between healthy and sustainable food consu
caused by the agricultural sector. Land
related responses that contribute to climate change adaptation
and mitigation can also combat desertification and land degradation and enhance food security

use) drivers are industry, AFOLU, buildings and transport
